title: Cryptocurrency
description: A technical cheatsheet for cryptocurrency systems: keys and wallets, addresses, transactions (UTXO vs account), fees/mempool, nodes and RPC, consensus, smart contracts, scripting/automation, security, operations, and troubleshooting (Bitcoin + Ethereum examples).

categories.description: Core ideas that apply across most cryptocurrencies and blockchains.

items.example:
Rule of thumb: custody = private key control.
If you cannot access or sign with the private key (or seed), you do not control the funds.

items.title: UTXO vs account model

rows: UTXO can only be spent once
Nonce can serialize from one account

items.example:
Bitcoin fee example: sum(inputs) - sum(outputs) = miner fee.
Ethereum fee example: gasUsed * (baseFee + priorityFee).

items.description: Common approach for deriving many keys from one seed.

rows: Tree of keys from a master seed
e.g. m/44'/0'/0'/0/0 for BTC legacy path.
xpub can derive addresses without spending capability.
Losing it = losing funds; store safely.

items.example:
Operational guidance:
- Store seed offline; consider metal backup.
- Do not type seed into random websites/tools.
- For organizations: consider multisig + documented recovery process.

items.description: Be careful: some tools output little-endian vs big-endian hex for certain fields (chain-specific).

items.title: Ethereum addresses (EIP-55 checksum)
items.description: Ethereum addresses are 20 bytes; checksum is mixed-case hex (optional but recommended).

rows: Case encodes checksum; helps catch typos.
Name resolves to address via ENS.

items.example: Many APIs accept lowercase, but UIs prefer EIP-55 checksummed addresses.

categories.title: Transactions and Fees
categories.description: How transactions are formed, propagated, confirmed, and paid for.

items.title: Lifecycle

rows: Wallet builds unsigned transaction with correct inputs/outputs or nonce/gas.
Private key signs (or multisig/hardware device signs).
Transaction sent to a node; propagates via P2P.
Nodes keep it if valid and pays adequate fee.
More blocks on top reduces reorg risk.
Chain-dependent: PoW probabilistic; PoS may have stronger finality.

items.example: For PoW chains, confirmation count is a risk-control policy decision (depends on value and chain security).

items.title: Fee knobs (high-level)

rows: Higher increases chance of mempool inclusion.
Allows fee bump by replacing transaction.
Tip to validators; affects inclusion speed.
Upper bound on gas usage; too low reverts/out-of-gas.

items.example: EIP-1559 style: effectiveGasPrice = min(maxFeePerGas, baseFee + maxPriorityFeePerGas).

items.title: Python: web3.py skeleton
items.description: Example outline for querying EVM networks (install: pip install web3).
items.example:
from web3 import Web3

w3 = Web3(Web3.HTTPProvider('http://localhost:8545'))
print('chainId', w3.eth.chain_id)
print('block', w3.eth.block_number)
print('balance', w3.eth.get_balance('0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000'))

categories.title: Security and Administration
categories.description: Operational security for keys, nodes, and infrastructure.

items.title: Key security checklist

rows: Detect stuck txs, reorgs, node lag

items.example: Treat seeds like root credentials. For teams, define: approval workflow, recovery drill, and incident response playbook.

items.title: Node hardening basics

rows: Bind to localhost; use reverse proxy with auth; restrict by firewall.
Track client releases and consensus changes; patch quickly on critical fixes.
Provision adequate IOPS; monitor growth; plan pruning/archive needs.
Back up wallet data and config; chain data is usually reproducible.
Collect logs; expose metrics if available; alert on sync lag.

items.example: Never expose an unauthenticated wallet-enabled RPC port to the internet.

categories.title: Troubleshooting
categories.description: Common operational issues across wallets, nodes, and networks.

items.title: Symptoms and fixes

rows: Check peers, disk usage, logs; ensure ports open; consider snapshot (chain-dependent).
Use RBF/fee bump if supported; or wait; avoid spamming replacements.
Compare to your node; wait for confirmations/finality.
Use checksummed formats (EIP-55, bech32) and copy/paste hygiene.

items.example: Always verify chain/network before sending: chainId (EVM) or network magic/parameters (UTXO chains).
